commander.name: Arturo Torriano
commander.previous_service: Preceded by Antonio Franceschini (18 May 1941 - 23 March 1942) and brief interim by Dino Parri (24 March - 8 April 1942)

command.headquarters_location: West of Tobruk, Libya (forward deployment during Gazala operations May-June 1942)

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for defensive operations, strained for sustained offensive. Primary constraints: fuel delivery from Tripoli (1,200km), British interdiction of coastal convoys. Water supply critical in desert positions. Division classified as 'auto-transportable' but lacked sufficient vehicles to move entire force simultaneously.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Coastal plain and rocky desert (Cyrenaica region, west of Tobruk)

subordinate_units.composition: 3 Infantry Battalions, Regimental HQ Company, Support Company
3 Infantry Battalions, Regimental HQ Company, Support Company

tactical_doctrine.role: Auto-transportable infantry division for defensive and limited offensive operations in North Africa. Designated for siege operations around Tobruk and holding static defensive lines.
special_capabilities: Adapted to North African climate and terrain
Effective in prisoner handling and mopping-up operations
known_issues: Insufficient motor transport for full divisional mobility
Vulnerable to armored attacks without German support
Water supply constraints in extended operations
Inadequate air defense against Allied tactical aviation
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Units trained in water discipline, desert navigation, and defense against armored warfare. Uniforms modified with tropical kit. Vehicles fitted with sand filters.

special_rules: Auto-transportable: Can move by trucks but not all at once
Desert Veterans: +1 to desert terrain familiarity
Siege Specialists: +1 in static defensive positions
historical_engagements: Second Battle of El Alamein (October-November 1942) - destroyed

source: US Army G-2, Order of Battle of the Italian Army, July 1943
TME 30-420 Handbook on Italian Military Forces, August 1943

chief_of_staff.reason: No divisional chief of staff information found in available sources
sources_checked: US Army G-2 Order of Battle July 1943
chief_of_staff.mitigation: Italian infantry divisions typically had a tenente colonnello (lieutenant colonel) as chief of staff; this would be standard practice

exact_vehicle_counts.reason: Specific vehicle inventories not documented in primary sources for 1942-Q2 timeframe
exact_vehicle_counts.estimate_method: Based on standard Italian auto-transportable division TO&E circa 1942, adjusted for North Africa deployment constraints and attrition

precise_personnel_breakdown_by_unit.reason: Unit-level strength returns not available for specific quarter; total division strength extrapolated from standard TO&E and attrition patterns
precise_personnel_breakdown_by_unit.estimate_method: Standard Italian infantry division establishment (12,500 men) reduced to ~7,200 accounting for North Africa attrition, disease, and supply constraints typical of 1942-Q2 period. Regiment strength estimated at 2,850 based on binary division structure.
